This appears to be a duplicate of https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/63324 -- to keep the development/review discussion in one place, please continue using that review instead of creating new ones.

The two scripts obmc-init and mmc-init are used for different builds and both would need the IMA & EVM support. Previously I added support for IMA & EVM to evb-as2600  (obmc-init) and now to p10bmc (mmc-init).

Are you suggesting to keep the patches close to each other in the patch sequence or merge them into one patch?

Oh!  Sorry, I missed the key detail that these were changing different files...the duplication between the two is unfortunate, but that's a preexisting condition and not something to be fixed in this patch.
Please switch to 4-space indentation.  You might use the beautysh config we have in openbmc-build-scripts, which currently isn't applied to this repo but will be in the future.
Done.
Are we able to determine this from `/proc/cpuinfo` instead?  Looking just for the string `qemu` somewhere in the dmesg output seems a little light.
I was looking through /proc/cpuinfo but it looks exactly the same as on the hardware. So this was the only way I found I could do this.

This looks somewhat suspect but it could just be that I haven't fully wrapped my mind around the design.

Why can we run code out of a potentially untrusted file system before we've loaded the keys and IMA policy?
The reason for this is that I could not figure out how to build these into the initramfs. Let me try it next week.
Fixed now in latest push. I figure out how to get keyctl into the initramfs.
Doesn't this lock us into a particular architecture and libc version?  What happens if these numbers change or we want to run this code on an aarch64 chip?

The reason why this line is necessary is because 
1) initramfs doesn't carry file signatures
2) once the IMA appraisal policy is active we can only use signed files and signed libraries

If this version changes, which probably happens rarely, one would have to adapt this script.
If this script needed to run also on aarch64 one may need to adapt the script again to support the libc from aarch64.

I tried to get rid of it by running activate_ima_evm later but the final switch_root needs this and the LD_LIBRARY_PATH to be set so that /sbin/init runs properly. Both are necessary.

If either one of those library related commands is missing I get this here:
```
[    4.766462] CPU: 0 PID: 1 Comm: switch_root Not tainted 6.5.4-12f22df-00079-g12f22df3cc2f #1
[    4.766674] Hardware name: Generic DT based system
[    4.767339]  unwind_backtrace from show_stack+0x18/0x1c
[    4.767930]  show_stack from dump_stack_lvl+0x40/0x4c
[    4.768067]  dump_stack_lvl from panic+0x114/0x350
[    4.768327]  panic from make_task_dead+0x0/0x184
[    4.768991] CPU1: stopping
[    4.769806] CPU: 1 PID: 0 Comm: swapper/1 Not tainted 6.5.4-12f22df-00079-g12f22df3cc2f #1
[    4.770279] Hardware name: Generic DT based system
[    4.770915]  unwind_backtrace from show_stack+0x18/0x1c
[    4.771542]  show_stack from dump_stack_lvl+0x40/0x4c
[    4.771798]  dump_stack_lvl from do_handle_IPI+0x18c/0x1c0
[    4.771993]  do_handle_IPI from ipi_handler+0x20/0x28
[    4.772181]  ipi_handler from handle_percpu_devid_irq+0x84/0x1c0
[    4.772463]  handle_percpu_devid_irq from generic_handle_domain_irq+0x30/0x40
[    4.772897]  generic_handle_domain_irq from gic_handle_irq+0x6c/0x80
[    4.773251]  gic_handle_irq from generic_handle_arch_irq+0x34/0x44
[    4.773494]  generic_handle_arch_irq from call_with_stack+0x18/0x20
[    4.773825]  call_with_stack from __irq_svc+0x98/0xb0
[    4.774062] Exception stack(0xbf85df70 to 0xbf85dfb8)
[    4.774330] df60:                                     00000003 00000001 00000001 40000000
[    4.774743] df80: 81186e00 80e05f14 81186e00 80e05f58 8000406a 410fc075 00000000 00000000
[    4.775095] dfa0: 0035935c bf85dfc0 8098880c 80988e50 600f0013 ffffffff
[    4.775495]  __irq_svc from default_idle_call+0x38/0xa0
[    4.775924]  default_idle_call from do_idle+0xac/0x120
[    4.776146]  do_idle from cpu_startup_entry+0x20/0x24
[    4.776402]  cpu_startup_entry from secondary_start_kernel+0x150/0x170
[    4.776685]  secondary_start_kernel from __enable_mmu+0x0/0x20
```

I think it should be fairly easy to adjust/extend this script to aarch64.

This here could work for allowing this to also work on aarch64 in the future. I am not sure whether the ld-linux library on aarch64 is going to be in /lib or /lib64, therefore there is an additional wildcard for this.

```
ldlib=$(ls /lib*/ld-linux-*.so.*)
mount --bind "$rodir/$ldlib" "$ldlib"
```

Is this what you would want here?

Yes, lets go ahead and do that.

You might want to do something to ensure `ldlib` only contains one element.  I think on x86-64 with 32-bit ABI support you can end up with multiple loaders?

On Fedora aarch64 glibc will provide /lib/ld-linux-aarch64.so.1 -- I suppose we can assume the same path for aarch64 on Yocto/OpenBMC? Os someone running OpenBMC on aarch64 already?

Right, ldlib must only have one element, and any wildcard is a potential problem. So should we really prepare the script for aarch64 when we cannot test it there yet?
Nuvoton's latest system is aarch64.  You can load that in QEMU and build the evb.

What is the command line for qemu to start the aarch64 image? OpenBMC build an 64MB image file and the following does not work with qemu 8.1.2:

```
> /usr/local/bin/qemu-system-aarch64 --version
QEMU emulator version 8.1.2 (v8.1.2)
Copyright (c) 2003-2023 Fabrice Bellard and the QEMU Project developers

> /usr/local/bin/qemu-system-aarch64   -machine npcm750-evb -nographic -no-reboot    -net nic -net user,hostfwd=:127.0.0.1:5722-:22,hostfwd=:127.0.0.1:5743-:443,hostfwd=udp:127.0.0.1:5723-:623 -drive file=./tmp/deploy/images/evb-npcm845/obmc-phosphor-image-evb-npcm845.static.mtd,format=raw,if=mtd,size=64M
qemu-system-aarch64: device requires 33554432 bytes, block backend provides 67108864 bytes
```

When using -drive file=...,size=32M (which is probably wrong anyway due to the size) I get no output on the console:

```

It isn't obvious to me why this is necessary.  Wouldn't the initramfs have been signed also?  Why are these versions "better"?  Also, how do you know they've actually been configured in a way that is compatible with the rest of the scripts?  Busybox config can be different between the initramfs and rootfs and while rootfs is often a superset config there is nothing to enforce that.

We can move the call to activate_ima_evm to be as late as possible in the initramfs, so immediately before `exec switch_root`.

However, once the IMA appraisal policy is activated, which should happen in the initramfs, then from that moment on only signed applications and libraries will be able to run. If we move it there then this greatly reduces the list under 'fn' below and maybe we can get rid of the signed libraries, but this depends on whether `exec switch_root` needs it or not.

I think we also need Milton's feedback on these.  Maybe it isn't necessary for the mmc scripts but ...

On the shutdown path for some of these init scripts we use the initramfs to perform updates of the rootfs.  If we've bind-mounted content from the rootfs we will likely crash (because we write data out from underneath the file system and if any code pages get evicted from memory the wrong content gets retrieved from flash).

We will need to ensure we un-bind-mount these explicitly in the shutdown path.  We also will end up running non-IMA signed code (which I think you said will be prohibited by policy).  We're going to have to figure out how to unload that policy?

The policy cannot be unloaded, otherwise an attacker could presumably also do this.

I was not aware of scripts in the shutdown patch. Once we come back from the exec switch_root in the init script(s), where does the execution continue?
How are the shutdown and updated scripts being triggered? If they access only signed tools then they should run fine.

The shutdown scripts are part of the initramfs.  We leave the rootfs/chroot environment and return back to init scripts.  These then run tools that are from the original initramfs.  I think you've said none of this is signed.

Yes, that's correct but I also don't *see* these script being run (with evb-ast2600) when the files are not signed nor do I see them fail when files are signed. I shutdown the system with 'shutdown -P now'

The shutdown script is used for static because we don't require space for a second copy of the filesystem in stable storage, so we instead use the systemd initramfs interface https://systemd.io/INITRD_INTERFACE/ to unmount the storage and then write the update images (It's not really a return to rootfs, but instead its a chroot or pivot_root to /run/initramfs and the /shutdown command is executed.  However, in today's initfs (used by static) the file tree is a copy of the initramfs, or at least several directories).  Likewise, the norootfs layout places the whole rootfs image as the initramfs, and so would need to get attributes reattached.

However, for the mmc and ubi we expect to have space for (at least) two copies of the root file system and therefore we write to an image slot that is not currently in use at the root filesystem.

So these are considerations for supporting ima appraisal in our other layouts.

However, this raises an alternate concern:   The code-update service currently mounts these alternate rootfs images into the filesystem, for the purpose of reading the (etc/osrelease -> ../usr/lib/os-release) usr/lib/osrelease file to parse its image.   Nominally these are obtained from the same vendor, but it points out the binaries possibly signed by the same key but from a different release will be mounted in the filesystem.   (I haven't looked if we could or do mount these noexec).

Now to evaluate the this function and its integration into the script.   Note this script was kept separate from `initfs` because there was a thought it could be kept simpler.  This is adding a significant block of code, but only to one of our four filesystem layouts.

Performing these bind mounts prevents switch_root from unlinking the underlying binaries, preventing the reclamation of space.

Form what I know the OpenBMC initramfs is already signed and its signature or hash is enforced by uboot. To enforce signatures for the root filesystem we want to leave the initramfs while already enforcing signatures. Even though this requires a bind mount at the moment, I actually don't see the files being mounted anymore once in rootfs -- at least 'mount -l -t bind' does not show them . 

Even today initramfs/cpio doesn't support xattrs and therefore the Dracut scripts cannot activate an IMA appraisal policy while in initramfs/cpio.

I have moved the invocation of the function to before the move of the mounts now.

I also tried writing the xattrs into the initrd. I enable CONFIG_TMPFS_XATTR and played around with the linux boot command line parameters to have the roofs be a tmpfs. I am not sure whether this is possible. Applying the file signatures from within obmc-init.sh currently always fails:

setfattr: /shutdown: Operation not supported

Actually with `console=ttyS4,115200n8 rootfstype=tmpfs rw` it does work now to write the xattrs.

obmc-init: There's this delay now when applying the signatures for executables and libraries to the initrd and its copy at run/initramfs:

```
[    2.344240] overlayfs: upper fs does not support RENAME_WHITEOUT.
Successfully loaded key onto .ima keyring

The problems I am having now without the bind mount:
- p10bmc: I can pass rootfstype=tmpfs along with root=PARTLABEL=${rootfs} on the boot command line but rootfstype=tmpfs seems to get ignored and none of the files can then be signed
- ast2600: I found out how to compile u-boot with rootfstype=tmpfs on the command line. However, during the first boot something modifies the u-boot env variables and sets the bootargs to  `console=ttyS4,115200n8 root=/dev/ram rw` making the next boot fail because the files in the initrd cannot be signed then due to the missing `rootfstype=tmpfs`. I don't know what is modifying the u-boot environment variables and why it's restoring them to values (`CONFIG_BOOTARGS`) that u-boot was not compiled with.

I could resolve the issue for ast2600. The issue was that the u-boot-fw-utils, which builds fw_printenv, builds the default environment into `fw_printenv` and therefore this project also needs a patch applied.
